sub_topic: Calculation of thermodynamic properties of molecules and reactions.
message_1:
What is the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) at 298 K for the following reaction:

2 H2O(l) -> 2 H2(g) + O2(g)

Given the following thermodynamic data:

ΔHf°(H2O) = -285.8 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(H2) = 0.0 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(O2) = 0.0 kJ/mol
ΔSf°(H2O) = 69.9 J/mol•K
ΔSf°(H2) = 130.6 J/mol•K
ΔSf°(O2) = 205.0 J/mol•K
message_2:
To calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔG = ΔH - TΔS

First, we need to calculate the enthalpy change (ΔH) and the entropy change (ΔS) for the reaction.

ΔH = ΣΔHf°(products) - ΣΔHf°(reactants)
ΔH = [2(0.0) + 1(0.0)] - [2(-285.8)]
ΔH = 571.6 kJ/mol

ΔS = ΣΔSf°(products) - ΣΔSf°(reactants)
ΔS = [2(130.6) + 1(205.0)] - [2(69.9)]
ΔS = 326.4 J/mol•K

Now we can calculate ΔG:

ΔG = ΔH - TΔS
ΔG = 571.6 kJ/mol - (298 K)(326.4 J/mol•K)(1 kJ/1000 J)
ΔG = 571.6 kJ/mol - (298 K)(0.3264 kJ/mol•K)
ΔG = 571.6 kJ/mol - 97.3 kJ/mol
ΔG = 474.3 kJ/mol

The Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) for the reaction at 298 K is 474.3 kJ/mol.
